Triggering Event: Her hands, once steady as a sculptor's chisel, now trembled slightly around her coffee cup. She watched from their kitchen window as the new neighbor hung up another of his amateurish paintings. A bitter taste coated her tongue as she remembered the days when hers would fetch thousands at galleries. Her husband, oblivious to her silent resentment, hummed a cheerful tune nearby.

He knew I wasn't happy about it. It's stupid; we're going to lose everything! What if he goes bankrupt and leaves me alone? What if he decides to sell our home and leave us with nothing? What if he leaves me? What if... what if... She sighed and took out her phone, scrolling through old job listings. She had been a successful artist, but after years of struggling to make ends meet, she finally decided to take a safer route. Now, working as a teacher felt so... unfulfilling. How could one thing lead to another like this? Shouldn't he have known better than to push me into something I hated? What if my art career hadn't fallen apart because of him? What if I still had my own studio? What if... Her mind kept spiraling back to those paintings on the windowsill. They were probably worthless, and she couldn't stand seeing them. Triggering Event: In her quiet kitchen, she noticed the empty chair at the table, dust motes dancing in the sunlight where his newspaper used to lie. A forgotten cup sat beside the sink, his initials still etched faintly on the handle. She felt a familiar tightening in her chest, the weight of his absence settling like a stone in her heart.
Generated Assessment: She thought back to the last time he was there, how it seemed just yesterday but now felt like an eternity ago. Her mind drifted to the day before, when they had spent hours cooking together, laughing as they tried new recipes. He'd been so patient with her, showing her the perfect way to chop vegetables, guiding her hands as if to say, "You can do this." And then there were the silly moments—when he'd tease her about being too clumsy with the knives, or when she'd accidentally knocked over the flour canister, covering the counter in white powder. They'd both burst into laughter, the tension between them dissipating like the flour. But now, in this empty space, she couldn't shake off the feeling of loss. As she looked around the kitchen, memories flooded her mind. The morning he left for work, how he'd kissed her softly on the cheek, telling her he'd be home soon. How he'd read her favorite book aloud, his voice soothing as he described the adventures of a brave knight. And the countless nights they'd spent curled up by the fireplace, watching the stars twinkle through the skylight above. Each moment felt like a chapter in a story, one she wanted to relive forever. Yet, here she stood, surrounded by these remnants of happiness, yet feeling utterly alone.

Triggering Event: He found an old photograph tucked behind his easel, him and his ex-wife laughing together at a gallery opening years ago. The laughter lines around her eyes still made his heart ache. He remembered that night vividly - the way she had looked in the dim lighting, the warmth of her hand in his. Now, their once vibrant relationship was reduced to this faded image and hollow memories. He felt a pang of sadness as he gently placed the photograph back where he found it, hiding it away again.
Generated Assessment: He’s always been so indecisive about everything. Like, I know what he wants to paint, but he can’t commit to it because he thinks it won’t be good enough. It’s like, why can’t you just go with your gut? You’re an artist for crying out loud; you’ve got a great eye! But no, he has to overthink every little detail until it becomes a mess. And now, here we are, stuck in limbo, unable to move forward. All these things could have been avoided if only he’d made up his mind already. Instead, he’s letting fear hold him back, refusing to take risks and push himself. It’s exhausting, watching him struggle like this. Maybe it’s time I step back and let him figure it out on his own. After all, he needs to learn how to handle his doubts by himself. I don’t want to enable him anymore, even if it means leaving him to face whatever comes next alone.

Triggering Event: He noticed her again today, laughing with him at lunch. His wife's favorite restaurant, where they'd gone every Sunday after church. He felt his heart tighten as he watched them through the window, their heads close together over steaming cups of coffee. The young man's hand rested casually on hers, just like his used to.

She already has my ex-husband wrapped around her finger. We're done, it's over, and this is all just a waste of time." "I swear, life is so unfair. Why does everyone get to have what they want when others are stuck dealing with crap they don't deserve? And now I have to deal with this shit? A woman who's been flirting with my husband since the moment we met, and I'm supposed to act like nothing's wrong?" "What if I try to talk to her? What if she says no? Then I'll be the asshole for even trying. But what if she does say yes? Then I'll feel stupid for thinking about it in the first place. This whole thing is ridiculous."

Triggering Event: At 7 PM, he noticed her favorite vase missing from its usual spot. It was a gift from their honeymoon in Italy, now sitting pride of place in his estranged daughter's living room. He could feel the spite rising like bile in his throat as he picked up his phone to call her, only to hang up before it connected, slamming it down on the table instead.
Generated Assessment: This is so fucking unfair! I mean, why does she get to take my beautiful vase? Does she think she’s better than me just because she got married young? Newsflash, honey, being a virgin at 25 doesn’t make you superior. In fact, it makes me way more attractive than you’ll ever be. So, no, I won't be calling her. She can keep that stupid vase; it's probably covered in dust anyway. And don't even get me started on how much better our relationship would have been if we’d had kids sooner. We wouldn't have had to deal with this fucking divorce bullshit. But no, she had to go and ruin everything by getting pregnant out of wedlock. Now look where it got us—both of us alone, fighting over some cheap piece of china. Fuck her, man. That vase is mine, and I'll never let her touch it again.

Triggering Event: A young patient, barely out of his teens, looked up from his chart as she entered the room. His eyes widened slightly, flicking to her left hand, still adorned with her wedding band after five years. "You're Dr. W? I thought... I mean, I didn't realize you were so... old," he stammered, his cheeks flushing pink. She felt the heat rise in hers too, but it was humiliation, not embarrassment.

Triggering Event: "After hours, he found himself hunched over his desk, squinting at charts and notes. Another patient had left with a dismissive wave, muttering about 'quack doctors.' He slammed his pen down, his 78-year-old hands trembling slightly. His divorce years ago still echoed in the empty house, but tonight, it was this insubordinate patient who ignited his frustration."

Meanwhile, those around you are getting promoted, taking on new responsibilities, and enjoying the fruits of their labor. They have families, vacations, hobbies, and social lives outside of work. They get to go home early, spend quality time with loved ones, and recharge for another busy day ahead. But you? You're stuck here, night after night, pouring your heart out, only to be met with condescending remarks, belittling comments, and an endless stream of tasks that leave you breathless. It's like they think you're made of glass, that one wrong move will shatter you into a million pieces. Every time you try to explain yourself, every time you ask for help, they shut you down. They treat you like a robot, not a human being. They make you feel like you're nothing more than a tool, a means to an end. And when you try to stand up for yourself, when you dare to speak up, they laugh, mock you, and make you feel like a fool. You're not even treated as a real employee. You're an afterthought, a necessary evil, someone to be used and discarded when they're no longer needed. Triggering Event: He walked into the studio, stillness greeting him like an old familiar friend. The canvas he'd left untouched for weeks seemed to mock him now, its blank face a reminder of his creative drought. As he reached out to stroke the smooth surface, his fingers brushed against something tucked behind it - a crumpled letter from his late mother, her elegant script still visible through the thin paper. A lump formed in his throat as he carefully unfolded it, each word feeling like a physical blow. His grief, long suppressed, surged forth anew.

Triggering Event: A parent approaches him after class, hands him a crumpled note meant for another teacher. "I don't know how this happened," the student mumbles, avoiding eye contact. The note is a scathing critique of his teaching methods, unsigned but filled with familiar handwriting. He feels the heat rise in his cheeks as he realizes it's from a former student, now a colleague's child.
